snippet: Perhaps from no other point can so good an impression of the actual position of Edinboro' be caught, as from that very railway sation, before the examination of details has confused the ideas. The North British Railway, end of the Great Northern—by which the London passenger arrives, enters the city from east by north, between the Calton Hill and Arthur's Seat, though much nearer the former on the right than the latter on the left; and disembarking from the cars and still looking forward or westward, that morning, I saw the Castle frowning on its tufted and beetling crags immediately ahead and only at a few hundreds of yards distance, while behind on either side the Calton Hill and Arthur's Seat formed the other two po nts of a triangle having the railway station for centre. Immediately at my side on the lest, the perilously tall buildings of the Old Town seemed scrambling up the side of the ravine, ten, twelve and even fourteen stories in height—so many, in fact, that genial Sir Walter is said to have perpetrated a bad pun by replying to a lady who asked him " how he could write so many stories ?" that " he had lived in Edinboro'; and every house, as she would find if she went there to look, supplied a dozen or two of them !" Antique, precipitous, threateninsr, almost tumble-down—so looked the Old Town ; while the very opposite in every feature was presented by the New Town rising on the other or northern side of the ravine —the two connected by the broad North Bridge spinning the depth in the immediate neighborhood of the railway station, and by a wide embankment called the Mound, crowned with the handsome buildings of the Scottish Antiquariau Society, between the two low-lying sections of the Princes' Street Gardens, and half way on towards the Castle.
